There is no variable declaration in Velocity. The variable is declared with the first value assignment. Values to variables are set with the #set statement:

{code}
#set($var="This is a string") or
#set($var='This is a string')
{code}

The difference between " and ' is that ' takes the whole string as it is and doesn't evaluate anything:

{code}
#set($string="This is a string")
#set($var1="$string")
#set($var2='$string')
var1= $var1 \\
var2= $var2 \\
{code}

The statements above will display:

{code}
var1= This is a string
var2= \$string
{code}

This is useful if evaluating should be ommited or if you have mix with " as in:

{code}
#set($query='document.id:"space/document name"')
query= $query \\
{code}

will display:

{code}
query= document.id:"space/document name"
{code}

If the assignement is not properly finished:

{code}
#set($string="This is a string)
{code}

an exception like this will be thrown:

A variable is used also with the $ (as seen above). If a variable is used with text directly following the variable, Velocity provides a seperator:

{code}
#set($var="Polar")
This is a training from $varion
{code}

displays

{code}
This is a training from $varion
{code}

In order to display Polarion the following code should be used:

{code}
#set($var="Polar")
This is a training from ${var}ion
{code}

will be shown as:

{code}
This is a training from Polarion
{code}

Sometimes the content of a variable could not be determined for instance if a method name could not be found. In these cases it is a good practice to escape via "!":

{code}
This is my e-mail account $email
This is my e-mail account $!email
{code}

If $email is not assigned a value, the two lines will display:

{code}
This is my e-mail account $email
This is my e-mail account 
{code}

{} and ! can be mixed:

{code}
This is my e-mail account $!{email}account
{code}

will work.

#spoiler("" "{code} ##This is my first Polarion Script
#set($var="Polarion")
This is my first velocity report inside of $var
$varisgood \\
${var}isgood \\
$!varisgood \\
$!{var}isgood
{code}")

In Velocity you´ve got the option to use basic mathematical operations:

{code}
#set( $value = 10)

#set( $add = $value + 2 )
#set( $sub = $value - 6 )
#set( $mul = $value * 3 )
#set( $div = $value / 4 )
{code}

Velocity supports the script writer with automatic substitution for getter and setter methods. The following statements are equal. Assume the variable $wi was assigned a workitem object:

{code}
$wi.getId()
$wi.id
but with mixed lower and capital letter 
$wi.getAvailableActions()
$wi.availableActions
{code}

It should be defined which kind of reference to use. It is good practice to either use one of these two possibilities. This support only works with properties not with methods which have parameters.

By assigning a value to a variable Velocity automatically assigns an object, which can be displayed. The following code will use the different datatypes from Velocity to assign them to different variables:

{code}
#set($string="This is a string")
#set($bool=true)
#set($number=2)
#set($array=[1,2,3,4])

$string.class \\
$bool.class \\
$number.class \\
$array.class \\
{code}

will display

{code}
class java.lang.String 
class java.lang.Boolean 
class java.lang.Integer 
class java.util.ArrayList
{code}

Getting data from an array is done by using the get method: 

{code}
$array.get(0), $array.get(1)
{code}

So an array index is starting at 0.

A muti dimensional array can be defined and called using the following code:

{code}
#set($testarray = [["one", "two", "three"],["four", "five", "six"]])
$testarray.get(1).get(1)
{code}

This also works with other objects retreived from any other call. Assume the varibale $wi was assigned a workitem object:

{code}
$wi.class \\
{code}

will display the following class name:

{code}
class com.polarion.alm.tracker.internal.model.WorkItem
{code}

Polarion objects without the class property are shown like this:

{code}
PObject(WorkItem; subterra:data-service:objects:/default/wiki${WorkItem}WIKI-19) 
{code}

This is a kind of debugging style to show the class names and/or the Polarion way to render the class.
An additionall debuggin option in Velocity gives you: #stop
Using #stop will stop the page rendering once this script has been reached inside of your code.

In Velocity it is not possible to create a new object. There is no "new" operator. Due to security reasons to creat new objects, it is necessary to implement a java program which instantiates a new object and returns it to Velocity.

On the extension page such a plugin is available: Polarion wiki scripting tools which should be mandatory if you work with Velocity.

After installing it, the variable $objectFactory is available. If you need a java.util.Map class then newMap() should be called:

{code}
#set($map=$objectFactory.newMap()) 
#set($oldValue=$map.put("key0","value0"))
#set($oldValue=$map.put("key1","value1"))
map= $map \\
{code}

will display all keys and their values.

{code}
map= {key0=value0, key1=value1} 
{code}

Similar to an array you get data out of a map by using the key as index:

{code}
$map.get( "key0")
{code}

#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($string="Daniel Morris")  
#set($number=30) 
#set($array=["John","Maria"]) 
 
Name: $string ($string.class) \\
Age: $number ($number.class) \\ 
Parents: $array.get(0), $array.get(1) ($array.class) \\
{code}")
#spoiler("" "{code}
#set($parents=$objectFactory.newMap()) 
#set($oldValue=$parents.put("Father","John"))
#set($oldValue=$parents.put("Mother","Maria"))
Parents = $parents \\
{code}")

Hint: The Map has no defined ordering of keys. So you need the key to get a value. In case you are planning to use $map.keySet() the order might be differnt than your entry. Because of this your output can be different than the image.

Velocity provides if/else and if/elseif/else statements. The following table defines the operators to be used.

Operator   Condition  Example
 ==  equivalent test, both variables should have the same data type  $var1 == $var2
 >  greater than test  $var1 > $var2
<   less than test  $var1 < $var2
>=   greater or equal than test  $var1 >= $var2
<=   less or equal than test  $var1 <= $var2
&&   logical AND test  $var1 && $var2
||   logical OR test  $var1 || $var2
!   logical NOT test, tests if the variable is not true  !$var1 
{code}
#if ($var1 == $var2)
  This is equal
#else
  This is not equal
#end

#if ($var1 == $var2)
  This is equal
#elseif ($var1 > $var2)
  This is greater
#else
  not equal and not greater
#end
{code}

The examples assume the variables are set to some meaningful values.

#end 
{code}")

If you are working with Wiki-Pages it is necessary to get data from the user in order to display information. Normally you have to deal with the the $request class to obtain the parameter from the URL. Polarion provides makro which gives you the opportunity to handle parameter from Wiki-Pages easily. The following statement defines a parameter:

{code}
(parameter:query|type=string|value=type:requirement)
{code}

The name is query and the type is a string. This definition can also be used for any parameter which are send to the current wiki page. If the wiki page is called with

{code}
http://server:port/polarion/#/wiki/space/document?query=type:requirement
{code}

the parameter query contains the parameter from the URL:

{code}
IGONRE ":" at start of "parameter:query" in next line paramter should be added without ":"
{:parameter:query|type=string|value=type:requirement}
query= $pageParameters.query \\
{code}

will display query=type:requirement if the page is called without any parameter. But if the page is called with ?query=type:usecase the page parameter is set to type:usecase.

If the user should enter data into the Wiki page, Polarion offers a macro to define the entry form and input fields specific to the datatype of the parameter. Details can be found in the Polarion Detailed Syntax help, available from nay wiki page in edit mode.

The Polarion API provides many methods to get workitem instances. One of the most commonly used method is the queryWorkItems method. The following API_Call returns all workitems of type requirement from the whole repository, the second call returns the requirements in the current proejct:

{code}
#set($results=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("type:requirement","id"))
results= $results \\
#set($results=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("project.id:$page.project AND type:requirement","id"))
results= $results \\
{code}

The method returns a collection which can be iterated or the number of workitems returned can be determined:

{code}
#set($number=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("type:requirement","id").size())
number= $number \\
#set($number=$trackerService.queryWorkItems("project.id:$page.project AND type:requirement","id").size())
number= $number \\
{code}

Polarion provides two different databases: a database which stores only the head revision of the object and a database, which stores all revisions of the objects. The database is read only so you can only get information out of it. you can´t write something directly into the database. As return value of your query you always get work items so Polarion will check if current user is allowed to see this kind of data. The changes of the database is done by job which is started every day at 7pm. With the historic database it is possible to get data from the historie not having calculated it with a workitem metric.

The search of the data in the SQL index is much faster than in the lucene index. All of the referenced objects in a workitem like custom fields, work records, linked workitems, comments, and so are stored in tables in order to keep to database redundant free. It is easy to get all custom field values for a given workitem or to get all custom fields with a specific value and retrieve the workitem ids by a single SQL query. Also to get all work records within a specific time period it is only easy and fast.

The database ist part of the sdk documentation and can be found here

If you need to get the linked workitems from a workitem or if you need to get all workitems linked with a specific linkrole only on SQL query is necessary. The table to look for is

{code}
STRUCT_WORKITEM_LINKEDWORKITEMS
{code}

This table contains all links if they are backlinks or links. The following SQL statement gets all backlinked workitems for a given workitem id:

{code}
$trackerService.getDataService().sqlSearch(

SELECT WI.C_ID "Requirement",
(SELECT WI.C_ID 

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

WHERE 
WI.C_PK = LW.FK_WORKITEM) "Linked WI", LW.C_ROLE "Linkrole" 

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.STRUCT_WORKITEM_LINKEDWORKITEMS LW ON WI.C_PK = LW.FK_P_WORKITEM 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.PROJECT PR ON WI.FK_PROJECT = PR.C_PK 

WHERE 
PR.C_ID = 'elibrary' 

ORDER BY 
WI.C_ID, "Linked WI")
{code}

and to get the linked workitems (TOP DOWN)

{code}
$trackerService.getDataService().sqlSearch(

SELECT WI.C_ID "Requirement",
(SELECT WI.C_ID 

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

WHERE 
WI.C_PK = LW.FK_P_WORKITEM) "Linked WI", LW.C_ROLE "Linkrole"

FROM 
POLARION.WORKITEM WI 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.STRUCT_WORKITEM_LINKEDWORKITEMS LW ON WI.C_PK = LW.FK_WORKITEM 

LEFT JOIN 
POLARION.PROJECT PR ON WI.FK_PROJECT = PR.C_PK WHERE PR.C_ID = 'elibrary' 

ORDER BY 
WI.C_ID, "Linked WI")
{code}
Hint: While browsing your database you might think about creating your tables by using some JOINS and return this data but please keep in mind this is not possible. 
$trackerService.getDataService().sqlSearch(java.lang.String sqlQuery) is only able to process a list of Work Item ID´s so not a complete table.

Rendering API was introduced to greatly simplify the custom development of reports. It provides programmers with an additional API layer that makes it much easier to render the data reliably for any export format. This new API can be used in Polarion Rich Pages but also in Classic Wiki.

Polarion´s new Rendering API can be found here 

Due to the fact Polarion´s predefined wiki macros are not usable in a Rich Page anymore these need to be replaced by Polarions new rendering API.

Nevertheless a macro like this:

{code}
 {workitem:$requirement.getId()|fields=title|expand=no}
{code}

can be easily replaced by te new rendering API.

{code}
$transaction.workItems().getBy().ids("$page.reference.projectId","$requirement.getId()").render().withLinks().withTitle()
{code}

Comparing these code snippets the wiki macro looks much easier to use but it´s functionality is much more limited than rendering the data using the new API. The macros are only able to work with a set of predefined paramters. Using the rendering API you have access to much more output options.

When we used wiki pages most of the time our starting point was $trackerService. Inside of Rich Pages there is also a variable which can bes uesd to get to all rendering objects as output you need. The vriable is $transaction as we´ve already seen in the previous example.

$transaction can be found in the Rendering API as class ReadOnlyTransaction  

Additionally to the scripting snippets before you can reuse your code snippets pretty simple to add additional fields or return completely different artifacts.

{code}
 {workitem:$requirement.getId()|fields=title,severity|expand=no}
{code}

Adds another field to your output data.

{code}
$transaction.workItems().getBy().ids("$page.reference.projectId","$requirement.getId()").render().withLinks().withTitle()
$transaction.workItems().getBy().ids("$page.reference.projectId","$requirement.getId()").render().fields().severity().render()  
{code}

Using the rendering API it´s the same base of code just changed to vizualize another field.

If you want to show a specific Test Run you can just change the code form workItems() to testRuns() . So the structure of the rendering API is more consitstent then the old API.

{code}
$transaction.testRuns().getBy().ids("$page.reference.projectId","$testRun.getId()").render().withLinks().withTitle()
{code}

Using the new rendering API we´ve started all the time using $transaction. When we create a widget we might not want to use static queries for our: tables, charts, etc.. We want to add parameters we can change to easily use widgets without knowing anything about the API.

A complete documentation how to develop widgets can be found here: Widget SDK 

To create a widget we need different kind of files to add our content.

In most of these files is not much content. In widget.properties e.g. you only define the name of the widget and the tab they should appear in:

Most of the content is available in parameters.vm and render.vm. In parameters.vm you can define all parameters your widget should have. Inside of render.vm the main part of your script will be added.

If we want to modify our previously used trace table as a widget we would put our script and into render.vm and add a parameter to select specific Work Items into parameters.vm

Example parameters.vm: 

{code}
$parameters.put("workItems", $factory.dataSet("Work Items").build())
{code}

Additionally to required fields and required roles you can add more functionalities to a Polarion workflow. Using Advanced workflow rules you can add functions and conditions during a workflow transition. So if you don´t want to allow users to switch into the next workflow state if a specific condition hasn´t met e.g. an author of an item or document shouldn´t be allowed to approve his own item, you can add a workflow condition. An example of such a condition is displayed below.

{code}
//
//	The script checks if the current user is also the author of the item
//
//	TRUE	the current user is not the author
//	FALSE	the current user is also the author
 
trackerService = workflowContext.getTrackerService();
 
//	get item you are changing the workflow
target = workflowContext.getTarget();

//	get current user
currentUser = trackerService.getProjectsService().getCurrentUser();

// check if author is similar to current user
blocked=!currentUser.equals(target.getAuthor()); 

// return string
returnValue="Author can´t be similar to person who "+ workflowContext.getTargetStatusId()+"s";

if ( (blocked == true) ) {
returnValue=true;
}
{code}

Additionally you might want to be able to execute a specific function while excuting your transition. In the example below you see an example of a project baseline which is created while a workflow status is changed.

{code}
// following objects exist in the context:
//     workflowContext (com.polarion.alm.tracker.workflow.ICallContext)
//     arguments       (com.polarion.alm.tracker.workflow.IArguments)


document = workflowContext.getTarget();

trackerService = workflowContext.getTrackerService();
trackerProject = trackerService.getTrackerProject(document.getProject().getId());
baselineManager = trackerProject.getBaselinesManager(); 
user = trackerService.getProjectsService().getCurrentUser();

baseline = baselineManager.createBaseline(document.getModuleName(),"Automatically generated Baseline due to LiveDoc approval",document.getLastRevision(),user);


baseline.save(); 
{code}

There is an extension for Polarion which makes it possible to easily run your own script files before and after saving or creating a Work Item. It's like the polarion workflow function but provides even more possibilities.

Download: http://extensions.polarion.com/extensions/134-fmc-work-item-save 

But please keep in mind these scripts are running on every save so you should be really carefull using these kind of scripts. If you have the option to use a workflow rule instead you should use a workflow rule.

The script you see below is adding the current user as title prefix. If it alreeady has it won´t add another prefix. As mentioned earlier this check happens on every save so you should limit it using the extension it is possible to limit it just to specific Work Items and specific projects due to naming conventions. It is also a best practice to add a check as starting point in your code so the script will only run if the check has passed e.g. in the script below it is first checking if the title already has a prefix before executing the code.

{code}
// This script prepends the username of the current user
// to the title or any workitem if the workitem was saved or 
// created.
//
// To make it work, you only have to copy this script 
// to "Polarion\scripts\workitemsave\pre-save.js" - that's it.
//
// Get the title of the workitem which should be saved and the
// current userid of the user
var oldtitle = workItem.getTitle();
var current_user_id = trackerService.getDataService().getSecurityService().getCurrentUser();

// Now we check if the workitem title already starts with the
// username. This can happen, as this script is called multiple times
// for each time the workitem is saved and we want the username only
// prepened once
if (oldtitle.startsWith(current_user_id) == false) {
	var newtitle = current_user_id + ": " + oldtitle;
	workItem.setTitle(newtitle);
}
{code}
